questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. He has cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening. His parents report frequent feedings and large-volume, greasy stools. Current medications include bronchodilators, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and fat-soluble vitamins. He is at the 18th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Auscultation of the lungs discloses diffuse wheezes. Examination shows a distended and tympanic abdomen with no tenderness or guarding. Which of the following would be a contraindication for administering one or more routine vaccinations in this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developing a fever after vaccination is not a contraindication for subsequent vaccinations. Although developing a fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving DTaP was previously a contraindication for subsequent DTaP vaccinations, it is now considered safe to administer the vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever at the time of vaccination, is a precaution rather than a contraindication for most vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis is not a contraindication for any vaccines. If possible, patients with cystic fibrosis should always be up-to-date with their vaccinations to prevent complications.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of severe allergic reaction (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or any of its components is a contraindication for any particular vaccine. However, a history of egg protein allergy without severe reaction to a vaccine is not a contraindication for egg protein-containing vaccines (e.g., flu vaccine) according to the Centers for Disease Control. Moreover, none of the routine immunizations scheduled at 4 months (rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV) contain egg proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain unstable neurological disorders (e.g., uncontrolled epilepsy, infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy) are contraindications for the pertussis vaccine, which is part of the DTaP vaccine. However, neither stable neurological disorders (e.g., controlled epilepsy), nor resolved neurological disorders, nor a history of uncomplicated febrile seizures are contraindications for any of the standard childhood vaccines.

E) CORRECT:

Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing intussusception. Although data is conflicting, a history of intussusception is considered a contraindication for receiving the rotavirus vaccine according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC). The exact mechanism by which the rotavirus vaccine leads to intussusception is unknown. Some studies suggest that since the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine the overall incidence of intussusception has not risen but the average age of onset in infants has decreased.

According to the CDC, other contraindications to the rotavirus vaccine are severe combined immunodeficiency and severe allergic reactions (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine.
questions.hint: This 4-month-old patient should receive his routine immunizations, including diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), pneumococcal conjugate, and rotavirus vaccines, the latter of which is contraindicated by one of the conditions listed below.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination dressed in a vampire costume. He is on his way to a Halloween party at an assisted-living facility in a suburb of Boston, where he works as a patient care attendant. He feels well. He has a history of hypertension that is well controlled. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 2 months ago during a routine examination. His current medications include lisinopril and metformin. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient's screening colonoscopy at the age of 55 years was normal. He smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 15 years ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Measurement of hemoglobin A1c obtained 2 months ago was 7.6%. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The American Diabetes Association recommends twice yearly hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) testing for patients with diabetes who have stable, controlled glucose levels and quarterly testing for patients with uncontrolled glucose levels. This patient's HbA1c was 7.6% (typical goal is < 7%) 2 months ago, and it should be rechecked in 1 month. HbA1c gives information on the 3-month average glucose concentration in the blood, and it is premature to recheck it at this visit.

B) CORRECT:

Annual influenza vaccine is recommended during the flu season (October–April in the Northern Hemisphere) for all individuals aged 6 months and older unless contraindicated. The influenza vaccination helps prevent influenza and its complications, especially in vulnerable populations like older adults, very young children, pregnant women, and individuals with chronic medical conditions. This patient with diabetes would particularly benefit from receiving the influenza vaccine because he is at higher risk of developing complications. Because he works at an assisted-living facility, he is also at increased risk of contracting and spreading the infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement is a screening strategy for prostate cancer. Current guidelines for screening with PSA measurement are controversial. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends shared decision-making regarding PSA measurement for men 55–69 years of age. Accordingly, this patient may consider screening, but there is another health maintenance recommendation that is clearly indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) who have a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because his last colonoscopy 3 years ago was normal, he does not require repeat screening at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Annual screening for lung cancer with a low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) scan is recommended in adults aged 50–80 years with ≥ 20 pack-year smoking history. This patient has a smoking history of < 20 pack-years (1/2 pack daily for 10 years is equivalent to 5 pack-years), so LDCT is not recommended for him.
questions.hint: This 58-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination in the fall (on Halloween in Boston) and requires standard health maintenance recommendations for his age and risk group.

questions.text: The physician recommends that the patient receive an influenza vaccine. The patient becomes nervous and reports that he has never received an influenza vaccination because of an allergy to eggs. The allergy was diagnosed many years ago after he developed hives upon eating scrambled eggs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform skin prick testing for egg allergy
End the examination without additional measures

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Most influenza vaccines are made from viruses grown in chicken eggs, raising the concern that allergic reactions might occur in those with a history of egg allergy. However, studies show that individuals with confirmed egg allergy can safely receive the influenza vaccine. According to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), egg allergy of any severity is not a contraindication for influenza vaccines. All vaccines should be administered in settings where treatment can be given for an acute allergic reaction. No special precautions beyond this standard are required for the administration of influenza vaccine to patients with egg allergy regardless of allergy severity. An influenza vaccine is contraindicated in individuals who meet the diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis following previous administration of the vaccine or following exposure to a component of the vaccine other than egg protein.

Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive either the recombinant influenza vaccine or the inactivated influenza vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Although skin testing before administration of the influenza vaccine was suggested for patients with a history of egg allergy in the past, it is no longer recommended. Even a confirmed allergy against egg proteins is not a contraindication for vaccination. Skin testing is recommended for evaluation of patients with a history of allergy to the vaccine itself (which may be caused by a component other than ovalbumin such as preservatives) or latex from gloves.

C) INCORRECT:

Influenza immunoglobulins are an experimental treatment for patients with active influenza infection. There is not sufficient data to support the effectiveness of the treatment, and it is not considered an effective form of prophylaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient would most likely benefit from a different recommendation. Ending the examination now would provide no benefit to the patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Oseltamivir can also be used for chemoprophylaxis of influenza in certain groups of patients (patients at high risk of complications of influenza, nonresponders to vaccination) after exposure to an infected patient. However, the CDC does not recommend routine use of oseltamivir for chemoprophylaxis of influenza.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy with Down syndrome is brought to the physician in October for a well-child examination. He is scheduled to receive diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) and influenza vaccinations at the current visit. His mother is concerned about giving the child any more vaccinations. She reports her son had a fever of 38.7°C (101.7°F) soon after he received his routine vaccinations at 12 months of age. He has had a runny nose for 2 days. He has a history of medically intractable seizures, with episodes that occur a few times a week and typically last 1–2 minutes. He was treated for intussusception at 6 months of age. He previously developed localized urticaria after the consumption of eggs. His immunizations are up-to-date. Medications include phenytoin, levetiracetam, and vitamin supplements. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows low-set ears, hypertelorism, and a flat head. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. After reviewing the patient's history and records, the physician recommends deferring the administration of DTaP. Which of the following best supports the physician's recommendation?

choices.text: History of allergic reaction to egg protein
History of fever after previous vaccination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe allergic reaction (e.g., angioedema, bronchospasm) to egg products warrants precaution when administering an egg-based vaccine such as inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV). Localized urticaria alone, however, is neither a contraindication nor a precaution for egg-based vaccines. Furthermore, the physician recommends deferring the administration of DTaP, which does not contain egg protein.

B) INCORRECT:

Isolated fever following any vaccination is neither a contraindication nor a precaution for the subsequent administration of any vaccine. Even a high fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving the DTaP vaccine is no longer considered a contraindication or precaution for subsequent DTaP or Tdap vaccinations.

C) INCORRECT:

Moderate or severe acute illness (with or without fever) is generally considered a precaution for vaccination. However, mild illness (e.g., upper respiratory infections, mild diarrhea) does not warrant the deferral of vaccination.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of intussusception is a contraindication to receiving rotavirus vaccine, not DTaP. As rotavirus vaccine is typically administered at 2, 4, and 6 months of age, this patient has likely received complete immunization against rotavirus.

E) CORRECT:

Uncontrolled seizure disorder is a precaution for the administration of the DTaP vaccine. Therefore, seizure disorders should be well-controlled prior to DTaP administration. The decision to immunize must be made on a case-by-case basis; a provider may recommend proceeding with vaccination despite known precautions if the benefits (i.e., protection) outweigh the risk of a potential adverse reaction. Other precautions for DTaP include progressive neurologic disorders (e.g., infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy), Guillain-Barré syndrome < 6 weeks following a previous dose of DTaP (or any tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine), Arthus reaction after DTaP, and moderate or severe acute illness (with or without fever).

Contraindications for DTaP include severe allergic reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis) or encephalopathy < 1 week following a previous dose of a pertussis-containing vaccine.
questions.hint: The CDC provides guidance on all recommended vaccines regarding contraindications and precautions (i.e., conditions that might increase the risk of a serious adverse reaction), which require the omission or delay of vaccination, respectively.

questions.text: A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of an itchy rash for the past 2 days. The patient's mother says she has noticed a few isolated skin lesions on her trunk 2 days ago. She received her routine immunizations 18 days ago. Her mother has been giving her ibuprofen for her symptoms. The patient has no known sick contacts. She is at the 71st percentile for height and the 64th percentile for weight. She is not in acute distress. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 26/min. Examination shows a few maculopapular and pustular lesions distributed over the face and trunk. There are some excoriation marks and crusted lesions as well. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: IgM and IgG antibodies binding to cellular antigens
Reactivation of virus dormant in dorsal root ganglion
Replication of the attenuated vaccine strain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune complex formation and deposition are characteristic of type III hypersensitivity reactions, which can be a complication of vaccination. An example is the Arthus reaction, a rare complication of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines that manifests with localized pain, edema, hemorrhage, and possible necrosis 4–12 hours after vaccination. A disseminated rash that appears 16–18 days after vaccination is not consistent with type III hypersensitivity reactions.

B) INCORRECT:

Antigen contact with presensitized T lymphocytes is the underlying mechanism of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, which may manifest with a maculopapular rash and pruritus. Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are typically triggered by antibiotics and appear within 5–14 days of starting the causative agent. A disseminated rash manifesting 16–18 days after vaccination is not consistent with type IV hypersensitivity reactions.

C) INCORRECT:

IgM and IgG antibodies binding to cellular antigens are responsible for type II hypersensitivity reactions. Examples of these reactions are ABO incompatibility and myasthenia gravis. Reports of type II hypersensitivity reactions accounting for vaccine-related adverse events are very rare. When they do occur, a localized eczematous rash at the injection site several hours after injection is typical.

D) INCORRECT:

Shingles is an infection caused by the reactivation of dormant varicella zoster virus (from a previous chickenpox infection) in the dorsal root ganglion. This condition can manifest with a maculopapular rash that progresses into vesicles. Unlike this patient's lesions, the shingles rash is typically very painful and manifests in a unilateral dermatomal distribution (usually 1-3 dermatomes). Moreover, this patient has no history of infection with the varicella zoster virus, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Left arm of a child showing multiple, uniform vesicles on an erythematous base. The dermatomal distribution (C8 and T1) is characteristic of shingles. Patients complain of severe pain prior to the appearance of lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

The crosslinking of preformed IgE antibodies is the underlying mechanism for type I hypersensitivity reactions. Type I hypersensitivity reactions may manifest as anaphylaxis. Although anaphylaxis may appear with erythema and pruritus, a maculopapular rash with crusted lesions is not typical of this condition.

F) CORRECT:

Replication of an attenuated viral strain in a vaccine is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings. Administration of the varicella vaccine can cause an attenuated form of chickenpox with a pruritic rash, maculopapular and/or pustular lesions, and crusting. After the initial vaccine, about 3% of patients will develop a mild form of varicella that has a very low risk of contagion. Both wild-type and vaccine-type strains of varicella can cause a rash. However, a rash that occurs > 2 weeks after varicella vaccination in a patient with no known exposure to infection is more likely caused by replication of the vaccine-type strain

Other vaccines that are typically given at 12 months of age include Hib, MMR, and polio.
questions.hint: The simultaneous appearance of lesions in various stages (papules, vesicles, and crusts) is characteristic of a disease that this patient was most likely recently immunized against.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with HIV 8 years ago. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He is planning a trip to Thailand with his partner to celebrate his 35th birthday in 6 weeks. His last tetanus and diphtheria booster was given 4 years ago. He received three vaccinations against hepatitis B 5 years ago. He had chickenpox as a child. Other immunization records are unknown. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His leukocyte count is 8700/mm3, CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 480 cells/mm3, and anti-HBs antibody titer is 150 mIU/mL. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B vaccine is generally recommended for all HIV-positive patients without immunity to hepatitis B. A booster dose following previous vaccination is required if the anti-HBs titer is < 10 mlU/mL. Since this patient's anti-HBs titer is 150 mlU/mL, he still has adequate immunity to hepatitis B.

B) INCORRECT:

The Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) live vaccine is given to select patient groups (e.g., children with a negative tuberculin skin test and continued high-risk exposure, healthcare workers on an individual basis) to prevent TB infection. However, it is no longer generally recommended in the US because of its variable effectiveness and the overall low risk of infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

In adults with a completed routine tetanus and diphtheria vaccination, booster doses are recommended every 10 years. In cases of injury with an increased risk of tetanus infection (e.g., animal bites), a booster dose is administered if the last immunization was ≥ 5 years ago. Since this patient's tetanus and diphtheria vaccination are up-to-date, no further boost is required at this point.

D) CORRECT:

Vaccinations in individuals infected with HIV should follow the generally recommended immunization schedule, including for live vaccines. Adults with uncertain immunity to measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) such as those with unknown vaccination status, no laboratory evidence of immunity, or born after 1957, should be given a dose of MMR vaccine, provided the CD4+ count is > 200 cells/mm3. Further recommendations for patients with HIV include vaccinations for pneumococcal disease and influenza (using the inactivated or recombinant influenza vaccines, as the live-attenuated vaccine is not recommended regardless of CD4+ count). The efficacy of immunization is reduced in patients with HIV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

The yellow fever vaccine should be administered to individuals traveling to endemic areas, including tropical Africa (e.g, Guinea, Ghana) and parts of Central and South America (e.g., Brazil, Ecuador). While live vaccines like the yellow fever vaccine can be safely administered in HIV patients with a CD4+ count > 200 cells/mm3 and no signs of immunocompromise (e.g., presence of AIDS-defining illness), yellow fever is not endemic in Thailand.
Image Description:

The green areas indicate regions where yellow fever is endemic. The WHO recommends vaccination for travelers to high-risk areas. When traveling to low-risk areas, there is no general recommendation; however, vaccination may be considered for longer stays or if there is a high risk of exposure. Proof of vaccination may be required when traveling to or from certain countries. Consult information from the WHO or CDC before traveling.

F) INCORRECT:

The standard immunization schedule should generally be observed in patients with HIV. Exceptions to this rule include a CD4 count < 200 cells/mm3 and the presence of AIDS-defining illnesses (e.g., Kaposi sarcoma, pneumocystis pneumonia). Since none of these exceptions are present, this patient should receive the generally recommended vaccinations.
questions.hint: The immunization schedule including live attenuated vaccines fully applies to patients with HIV infection and a CD4+ count above 200 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician in June for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with HIV infection 3 months ago. He has been taking combined antiretroviral therapy since then. He feels well. He is sexually active with both female and male partners and regularly uses barrier protection. He does not smoke and drinks 2–3 glasses of wine on weekends. The patient did not receive any childhood vaccines besides the hepatitis B vaccine. Six years ago, he received the tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccination. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is 190/mm3. Which of the following immunizations should be administered at this time?

choices.text: Tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against varicella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count < 200/mm3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm3, he should receive this vaccine to protect him against chickenpox and shingles.

B) INCORRECT:

The tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccination is indicated in adults who did not receive the usual schedule of vaccinations during childhood, as is the case in this patient. Booster vaccination with tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) is required every 10 years in order to maintain full immunity. However, this patient received his Tdap vaccine only 6 years ago, which means that he will not require a booster dose of the Td vaccine for another 4 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Annual Influenza vaccination with the inactivated or recombinant vaccine is highly recommended, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as this patient. However, he is currently being seen in the month of June, which is still too early for the influenza vaccine. For maximum protection from the influenza virus, he should receive the vaccine at a follow-up visit in the early fall. The live-attenuated influenza vaccine should not be administered to individuals with HIV infection, regardless of their CD4+ T lymphocyte count.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against measles, mumps, and rubella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live attenuated vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of < 200/mm3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm3, he should receive this vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk for infection, including with human papillomavirus (HPV). However, the same guidelines apply to immunocompromised individuals as the general population, which is that HPV vaccination is recommended in all individuals ≤ 26 years of age. While the FDA has approved the HPV vaccine for individuals up to 45 years of age, the decision to receive a vaccine after 26 years of age is established on an individual basis.

F) INCORRECT:

Pneumococcal polysaccharide 23 vaccine (PPSV23) is recommended for individuals aged 19–65 years who are immunocompromised (e.g., those with HIV). However, the PPSV23 vaccine should not be administered before the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, PCV15. Because this patient's vaccination history is unknown, he should receive the PCV15 now and return in at least 8 weeks to receive the PPSV23. Alternatively, individuals can be given one dose of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine PCV20 without subsequent need for PPSV23.

G) CORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection or chronic liver disease are at increased risk of developing a severe disease following infection with the hepatitis A (HepA) virus. The HepA vaccine is part of the routine vaccine regimen and is recommended for all individuals between 12 and 23 months of age with a second dose administered at least 6 months later. Any adult who did not receive the vaccine and is at high risk for HepA infection or severe disease should be vaccinated. The HepA vaccine is a killed vaccine and can be safely administered even if the patient has a low CD4 T-cell count.

Risk factors for HepA infection include recent travel to an area where the virus is endemic, recreational drug use, and men who have sex with men.
questions.hint: Special attention should be paid to the selection of appropriate vaccinations in patients with HIV, especially those with a low CD4 count, which indicates severe immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of chest pain for 2 hours. Eight days ago, she was admitted to the hospital for treatment of low-grade fever, malaise, and sore throat. The hospitalization was complicated by pharyngitis with pseudomembrane formation and severe cervical lymphadenopathy briefly requiring intubation. She has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. Serum studies show elevated cardiac troponins. An ECG shows diffuse T wave inversions and prolonged PR interval. Administration of which of the following at the time of her previous admission is most likely to have prevented this patient's cardiac symptoms?

choices.text: Denatured bacterial toxin that contains an intact receptor binding site
Antibiotic that binds to penicillin-binding protein 3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of a denatured bacterial toxin that contains an intact receptor binding site (e.g., diphtheria toxoid) provides active immunity. However, active immunity takes several weeks to develop; therefore, administration of the diphtheria vaccine would not have helped at the time of admission. Previous vaccination certainly would have dramatically reduced the odds of contracting diphtheria.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium is an electrolyte that reduces cardiomyocyte excitability and is typically administered to protect the myocardium from the deleterious effects of hyperkalemia. Although hyperkalemia can present with malaise and prolonged PR interval, as seen in this patient, elevated cardiac troponins, diffuse T wave inversions, and chest pain are not common. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is strongly suggestive of diphtheria, for which calcium is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Monobactam antibiotics (e.g., aztreonam) have intrinsic β-lactamase activity (which binds PBP) but are effective against gram-negative bacilli only. C. diphtheriae is a gram-positive rod, so it is not susceptible to monobactam antibiotics. Appropriate antibiotics, such as penicillin (or other beta-lactam antibiotics), should be given to patients with diphtheria to decrease the transmissibility and improve the course of the acute infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is a salicylate that works by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. It can be used in the treatment of Kawasaki disease to decrease the risk of coronary artery aneurysms. Although Kawasaki disease can also present with fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, chest pain, and elevated cardiac troponins (as a result of myocardial ischemia), this patient lacks other typical features, such as bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, mucositis, and rash. Furthermore, the presence of pharyngitis with pseudomembrane formation is highly suggestive of diphtheria.

E) CORRECT:

Immediate administration of immunoglobulin that targets circulating proteins (i.e., diphtheria antitoxin) provides passive immunity and is a critical part of diphtheria treatment. The use of an antitoxin is imperative as the clinical features of diphtheria are not caused by the pathogen itself but rather by the exotoxin (diphtheria toxin) that C. diphtheriae produces. The antitoxin can only neutralize unbound toxin and should therefore be administered early in the course of the disease.
questions.hint: Pharyngitis with pseudomembrane formation and cervical lymphadenopathy (“bull neck”) is suggestive of diphtheria. The patient's signs and symptoms of cardiac dysfunction (chest pain, elevated cardiac troponins, ECG abnormalities) are indicative of myocarditis, a concerning complication of diphtheria.

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She has no history of serious illness. She receives a vaccine in which a polysaccharide is conjugated to a carrier protein. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely target of this vaccine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine that contains denatured diphtheria toxin with an intact binding site for the receptor in the host's body. A carrier protein is not required to induce an immune response.

B) INCORRECT:

The tetanus vaccine is a toxoid vaccine that contains denatured tetanus toxin with an intact binding site for the receptor in the host's body. It is a protein-based vaccine, rather than polysaccharide-based.

C) INCORRECT:

The hepatitis A vaccine is an inactivated vaccine that contains surface antigens of the hepatitis A virus. These antigens are inactivated but capable of producing a humoral immune response (synthesis of anti-HAV IgG). A carrier protein is not required to boost immunogenicity.

D) INCORRECT:

The varicella zoster vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, which contains living pathogens that have been modified to lose their pathogenicity. A carrier protein is not required.

E) CORRECT:

Conjugate polysaccharide vaccines are used to target encapsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae. In young children (< 2 years), capsular polysaccharide antigens do not produce a sufficient immune response. Therefore, conjugate vaccines are administered to ensure sufficient immunization via activation of T cells, which stimulate a more rapid and long-lasting immune response. In addition to the PCV15 and PVC20, other conjugate vaccines include the Hib vaccine and meningococcal vaccine.

F) INCORRECT:

The pertussis vaccine is an acellular inactivated vaccine that contains subunits of pertussis antigens capable of inducing an immune response without the help of a carrier protein.
questions.hint: A conjugate vaccine contains capsular polysaccharide antigens that are conjugated to carrier proteins, which enhances immunogenicity by promoting T-cell activation.

questions.text: A 3255-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. On the day of her birth, she is given a nonconjugated routine childhood vaccine that contains a noninfectious glycoprotein. This vaccine will most likely help prevent infection by which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine contains a capsular polysaccharide conjugated to an immunogenic protein (conjugate vaccine). The Hib vaccine is generally administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth; it is not administered on the first day of life.

B) INCORRECT:

The inactivated poliovirus vaccine, which contains noninfectious virions, is given at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth. It is not administered on the first day of life.

C) INCORRECT:

The acellular pertussis vaccine is part of the DTaP vaccine, which is composed of the Corynebacterium diphtheriae toxoid, Clostridium tetani toxoid, and subunits (e.g., toxoid, adhesins) of Bordetella pertussis. Children receive the DTaP series at the age of 2, 4, and 6 months, with boosters at the age of 15-18 months and 4–6 years. The DTaP vaccine would not be administered at birth.

D) INCORRECT:

The rotavirus vaccine, which is a live attenuated vaccine, contains virions that are able to replicate within the host's body, not a noninfectious glycoprotein. Moreover, the rotavirus vaccine is administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth; it is not administered on the first day of life.

E) CORRECT:

Infection by hepatitis D virus (HDV) can be prevented by hepatitis B vaccination. On its own, HDV is “defective” and unable to cause disease. HDV requires the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) for replication (viral complementation). HBsAg, a noninfectious glycoprotein, is the antigen used to make the hepatitis B vaccine. Hepatitis B is spread through sexual activity, via needle sharing, or at birth from the mother to child.

The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) currently recommends that all infants should receive the hepatitis B vaccination within 24 hours of birth, and subsequently at 1–2 months and 6–18 months of age.
questions.hint: The antigen in this vaccine protects against two pathogens simultaneously.

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a routine well-child examination. She is given a vaccine that contains polyribosylribitol phosphate conjugated to a toxoid carrier. The vaccine is most likely to provide immunity against which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae infections can be prevented with pneumococcal conjugate vaccines. Like the vaccine this patient received, pneumococcal vaccines are derived from purified capsular antigens. In order to elicit an immune response in infants and toddlers, the capsular antigens are conjugated to inactivated diphtheria toxin to stimulate T cells, which causes a more rapid and long-lasting immune response. However, the pneumococcal antigens are not polyribosylribitol phosphate, meaning it is not the vaccine in question. Pneumococcal vaccination is most often administered at 2 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Poliovirus can be prevented with the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV, Salk strain). A live attenuated vaccine (the Sabin vaccine) is also available. Unlike the vaccine mentioned here, there is no immunogenic polysaccharide fragment in polio vaccines. Because the live attenuated vaccine is associated with the rare adverse effect of vaccine-induced polio, the inactivated vaccine is recommended (it does not carry a risk of causing polio). The first dose of IPV is administered at 2 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, which can be prevented with a vaccine containing the inactivated diphtheria toxin. Because there are no clinically available vaccines against this organism that rely on a capsular protein, it is not the vaccine in question here. The vaccine is usually administered along with the tetanus and pertussis vaccine as the DTaP vaccine at 2 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis virulence can be reduced by giving conjugate meningococcal vaccines to high-risk individuals. Capsular polysaccharides from the four most common virulent strains of N. meningitidis are typically conjugated to a diphtheria toxoid protein for enhanced immunogenicity. Unlike the vaccine mentioned here, the antigens are not polyribosylribitol phosphate. Furthermore, meningococcal vaccination is not routinely recommended at such an early age.

E) CORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) produces a polyribosylribitol phosphate capsule. This organism causes invasive diseases such as meningitis, epiglottitis, and septic arthritis, especially in early childhood. The PRP capsule is a strong virulence factor and plays a key role in the organism's pathogenicity by protecting it from complement-mediated lysis and phagocytosis. Vaccination is extremely effective at preventing these infections. Unencapsulated, nontypeable H. influenzae is not covered by the Hib vaccine; it is part of the normal nasopharyngeal flora and can cause otitis media, sinusitis, and conjunctivitis in children who have received the Hib vaccine.

The Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine contains the capsular polysaccharide conjugated to an immunogenic protein, such as diphtheria toxoid (conjugate vaccine). The Hib vaccine is generally administered at 2, 4, and 6 months after birth.

F) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis infection can be prevented with the acellular pertussis (aP) vaccine. The aP vaccine contains the inactivated pertussis toxin rather than polyribosylribitol phosphate capsular proteins. The host immune system produces protective antibodies against the toxin, reducing the odds of developing an infection in cases of exposure to B. pertussis. The first dose of aP is administered at 2 months.
questions.hint: A polyribosylribitol phosphate (PRP) capsule is an important virulence factor for certain strains of this pathogen.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has been inconsistently taking combined antiretroviral therapy for the past 5 years. She did not receive any childhood vaccinations because her parents were against them. During the consultation, the patient says that she wants to catch up on the missed vaccinations. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of 180/mm3. Administration of which of the following vaccines should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Bordetella pertussis is an inactivated vaccine. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Human papillomavirus (HPV) is an inactivated vaccine. One of the main benefits of vaccination is protection against HPV-associated cervical cancer. HPV immunization is approved for individuals 11–26 years of age. Patients with HIV should receive HPV immunization during this same interval. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

C) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Haemophilus influenzae (Hib vaccine) is an inactivated vaccine that prevents invasive infection with H. influenzae type b (Hib). A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Hepatitis B virus is an inactivated vaccine. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines. In fact, it is strongly recommended that patients with HIV receive the hepatitis B vaccination because of the elevated risk of chronic infection in this patient group.

E) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Clostridium tetani is a toxoid vaccine (inactivated vaccine). A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for toxoid-based immunization.

F) CORRECT:

The vaccine against varicella zoster virus is a live attenuated vaccine. It is recommended in HIV patients with a CD4 count > 200/mm3. However, a CD4 count of 180/mm3, as seen in this patient, is a contraindication for live vaccines (such as varicella, yellow fever, mumps, measles, and rubella) because of the risk of vaccine-related reactivation of the attenuated virus.
questions.hint: Live attenuated vaccines should be avoided in patients with HIV infection and a CD4 count < 200/mm3.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a scheduled immunization visit. The patient's father reports that the patient had continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. He has noticed that the patient keeps tugging at his left ear. The patient was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8ºC (100.1ºF); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane; examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Treatment with ibuprofen and amoxicillin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician regarding immunization?

choices.text: Administer standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit
Administer weight-adjusted doses of all due vaccines after the illness resolves
Administer standard doses of all due vaccines after 5 weeks
Administer weight-adjusted doses of all vaccines due at this visit
Administer standard doses of inactivated vaccines at this visit and live vaccines after the illness resolves

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient should receive the standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit. Neither mild acute illness (e.g., upper respiratory tract infection, otitis media, low-grade fever, mild diarrhea) nor current antibiotic therapy are contraindications for vaccination (except for oral live typhoid vaccine, because antibiotics might compromise the immune response to this vaccine). All children must be immunized with the standard doses of vaccines according to their chronological age; doses should not be adjusted to weight or gestational age.

The only vaccine that depends on the child's birth weight is the first dose of HepB vaccine; infants with a birth weight < 2 kg should receive the first dose of the vaccine at 1 month of age or at hospital discharge, whichever occurs first.

B) INCORRECT:

Valid contraindications for vaccination include previous severe allergic reactions related to vaccination (e.g., anaphylaxis) and severe allergies to components of a vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness with or without fever is a precaution for vaccine administration. Mild illnesses, such as otitis media and low-grade fever are not contraindications for vaccination. Adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

C) INCORRECT:

Preterm infants should be vaccinated at the same chronological age, according to the same schedule, and using the same precautions as full-term infants. Correction for gestational age is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaccination is contraindicated in patients who have experienced a severe allergic reaction to a prior dose or component of a vaccine, which is not seen here. However, adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

E) INCORRECT:

Live attenuated vaccines are not recommended in pregnant and/or immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those receiving immunosuppressive therapy, patients with congenital immunodeficiencies, severely immunocompromised patients with HIV). In such cases, the standard doses of inactivated vaccines might be indicated, but the administration of live vaccines should be postponed until after delivery or until the patient is no longer considered immunocompromised. This patient has neither of these contraindications, so another approach would be more appropriate.
questions.hint: If there are no absolute contraindications, immunizations indicated at 12 months include the fourth Hib dose; fourth PCV15 dose; first measles, mumps, and rubella dose; and first varicella dose.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. He is scheduled to receive the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP), rotavirus, hepatitis B, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate, and inactivated poliovirus vaccines. He appears well and has no history of serious illness. The mother reports that, after receiving multiple vaccines at the previous well-child visit, he had a swelling on the left thigh, fever, and loss of appetite for two days. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 70th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits and the remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. At the current visit, the child's father says, "We don't think our son needs so many vaccinations. We are worried that too many vaccinations would weaken his immune system." Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?

choices.text: "Vaccines can occasionally have minor side effects but their benefits far outweigh any of the associated risks. Are you concerned about the side effects of the previous vaccine?"
"This must be a difficult decision for you. You are legally allowed to refuse vaccination of your children by filling out a vaccination waiver form."
"I understand that you are concerned. As a compromise, would it be acceptable if we vaccinate your son against one disease at this visit?"
"Vaccines strengthen rather than weaken the immune system. May I provide you with some resources on the benefits of vaccines?"
"We both want what is best for your child. Why do you think your son's immune system would be weakened by too many vaccines?"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While the statement in this response is true, the closed-ended question in the second part of the response is not likely to facilitate a discussion that would elicit more information from the parents regarding their hesitancy. Additionally, the physician should not prematurely assume that the reason behind the father's refusal to vaccinate his son is related to the side effects of the previous vaccination.

B) INCORRECT:

This response reflects empathy toward the father's concerns, which is appropriate. However, it is premature to suggest a vaccination waiver form at this stage.

C) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend the use of simultaneous vaccinations and combination vaccines in order to reduce the number of visits and pain associated with the injection. Although this response shows empathy and tries to find a compromise, it is inappropriate for medical reasons.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this statement is true, it may be perceived as dismissive because it fails to elicit more information from the parents regarding their hesitancy. Providing parents with reliable information about the risks and benefits of vaccinations is important, but it should be done at a different stage of the conversation.

E) CORRECT:

When parents refuse or are hesitant to vaccinate their child, the situation is an ethically challenging one for physicians. In this scenario, the most appropriate initial approach by the physician is to show empathy, establish a therapeutic alliance, and address the parents' concerns regarding vaccination by practicing reflective listening. Asking open-ended questions will facilitate discussion and help the physician explore the root cause behind vaccination hesitancy. The physician should then provide reliable information on the risks and benefits of vaccination and attempt to address and correct misconceptions to ensure that an informed decision can be made. If an agreement is not reached, the topic should be revisited on subsequent visits.
questions.hint: When dealing with vaccination refusal or hesitancy, the physician must first try to identify and address the parents' concerns. Certain interviewing techniques should be used when trying to gather more information and learn more about parents' perspectives.

questions.text: An investigator is developing a vaccine for a newly identified virus. After the inoculation of the experimental vaccine, a lipid nanoparticle is engulfed by the projections of the dendritic cell membrane and transported intracellularly by an endosome. The endosomal content is released into the cytosol, where a ribosome binds to it. Following translation, the antigenic protein is either broken down into peptides by the proteasome and presented via major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I, or exocytosed, taken up by phagocytes, and presented via MHC class II. These findings are most similar to the mechanism of which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In live attenuated vaccines (e.g., VZV, rotavirus), a modified (i.e., attenuated) functioning virus is inoculated in the patient. Usually, the modified virus does not cause disease. In viral-infected cells, cytosolic antigenic proteins are either broken down into peptides by the proteasome and presented via MHC class I or they are exocytosed, taken up by phagocytes, and presented via MHC class II. Although antigenic protein processing and presentation are similar to what is described in this case, the mechanism of antigenic protein formation is different; in patients inoculated with live attenuated vaccines, cells are infected by the virus and not with material that is ready for translation within the host cell to form the antigenic protein.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxoid vaccines (e.g., diphtheria, tetanus) use bacterial toxins in which the toxicity has been inactivated while immunogenicity is maintained through intact receptor binding sites. Bacterial toxins are taken up by cells with endocytic activity (e.g., dendritic cells) and are processed in the endosome, after which viral antigens bind to MHC class II molecules and are then presented on the cell surface, triggering a mostly humoral response. There is no antigen presentation via MHC class I when using toxoid vaccines.

C) CORRECT:

This mechanism of action is characteristic of mRNA vaccines. These vaccines contain mRNA coding for a specific antigen (e.g., spike protein in COVID-19 vaccines), which cells use to produce the desired antigenic protein. mRNA strands are encapsulated in lipid nanoparticles (LNPs), which protect the strands from extracellular enzymatic digestion and facilitate uptake into cells. mRNA vaccines are highly effective and induce both humoral and cellular immune responses. There is no risk of infection because mRNA is nonpathogenic. These vaccines are also safe to use during pregnancy because mRNA does not interact with the DNA, so there is no risk of insertional mutagenesis.
Image Description:

The mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccines contain mRNA coding for the spike protein of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. To increase stability and enhance uptake into cells, the mRNA strands are encapsulated in lipid nanoparticles.

Within the cell, the mRNA causes transient, local expression of the spike protein, which is then either processed and presented via MHC-I molecules or exocytosed. Exocytosed spike proteins are taken up by phagocytes (especially dendritic cells in the muscle) and presented via MHC-II molecules. Presentation of the spike protein fragments via MHC-I and MHC-II leads to the development of a specific immune response against the spike protein.

D) INCORRECT:

Subunit vaccines (e.g., hepatitis B, HPV) use inactive antigenic subunits of pathogens to trigger an immune response. Antigenic subunits are taken up by cells with endocytic activity (e.g., dendritic cells) and processed by the endosome, after which viral antigens bind to MHC class II molecules and are presented on the cell surface, triggering a mostly humoral response. There is no antigen presentation via MHC class I when using subunit vaccines.

E) INCORRECT:

Inactivated whole virus vaccines (e.g., hepatitis A, influenza) trigger an immune response by using unchanged surface epitopes from dead or inactivated pathogens. A whole virus, not a lipid nanoparticle, is taken up by cells with endocytic activity (e.g., dendritic cells) and processed by the endosome, after which viral antigens bind to MHC class II molecules and are presented on the cell surface, triggering a mostly humoral response. There is no antigenic presentation via MHC class I in this type of vaccine.

F) INCORRECT:

Viral vector vaccines (e.g., ebola) use a modified unrelated virus (e.g., adenovirus) as a nonpathogenic vector, which delivers genetic code to cells that contains instructions for the production of the desired antigen. In viral vector vaccines, a virus, not a lipid nanoparticle, is engulfed by the cells.
Image Description:

The vector-based COVID-19 vaccines are based on various recombinant adenoviruses (e.g., the chimpanzee adenovirus in AZD1222 by AstraZeneca, or the human adenovirus type 26 in Ad26.COV2.S by Janssen).

The recombinant DNA of the vector virus codes for the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is synthesized by the host cell. The spike protein is then either processed and presented via MHC-I molecules or exocytosed. Exocytosed spike proteins are taken up by phagocytes (esp. dendritic cells in muscle) and presented via MHC-II molecules. Presentation of the spike protein fragments via MHC-I and MHC-II leads to the development of a specific immune response against the spike protein.
questions.hint: A vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 uses this mechanism of action.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman with stage III breast cancer presents for routine care. She underwent a left-sided modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph-node dissection 2 months ago and is currently receiving adjuvant chemotherapy with docetaxel, carboplatin, and trastuzumab.
A review of her immunization record shows the following:

13-valent pneumococcal vaccine 2 years ago
Recombinant zoster vaccine 4 months ago and 2 months ago
23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 2 months ago
Inactivated influenza vaccine 2 months ago

She reports that she had chicken pox as a child and has never received the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine. She is up to date with her Covid-19 and respiratory syncytial virus vaccinations.
Which one of the following vaccination plans is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: No vaccinations needed at this time
Revaccinate now with inactivated influenza vaccine
Revaccinate now with 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide booster

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with cancer are at high risk for many types of viral infections. However, if they are actively receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy, they should not be given any live-organism vaccines, such as the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine or varicella vaccine.

Key learning point: Patients with cancer who are actively receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy should not be immunized with live-organism vaccines, such as the varicella vaccine or the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Revaccination for influenza and pneumococcal infection is not routinely required after the administration of chemotherapy. This patient has already received two doses of the recombinant zoster vaccine, and reimmunization is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient is older than 65 years of age, pneumococcal vaccination is indicated, but she is already up to date on this immunization series, having recently received both the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide booster. She will be eligible for the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 5 years after her last pneumococcal vaccine dose.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with cancer are at high risk for many types of viral infections. However, if they are actively receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy, they should not be given any live-organism vaccines, such as the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine or varicella vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with cancer are at high risk for many types of viral infections. However, if they are actively receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy, they should not be given any live-organism vaccines, such as the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine or varicella vaccine.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents to establish primary care. She immigrated to the United States from Mexico 8 months ago. She has acute lymphoblastic leukemia and is currently being treated with chemotherapy.
The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, and she appears well.
Review of her records reveals that she has received the following vaccines:



Birth
2 months
4 months
6 months
12 months
15 months


Hepatitis B virus
X
X

X

X

X




Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis

X

X



Haemophilus influenzae type b

X
