X
X



13-Valent pneumococcal conjugate

X
X
X
X



Inactivated poliovirus

X
X
X




Hepatitis A virus




X



Measles-mumps- rubella




X



Varicella-zoster virus




X



Which one of the following sets of vaccines should this patient receive at today’s visit?

choices.text: Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, measles-mumps-rubella, varicella-zoster virus, and hepatitis A virus
Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, inactivated poliovirus, measles-mumps-rubella, varicella-zoster virus, and hepatitis A virus
Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis A virus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Children receiving chemotherapy are immunosuppressed and should not receive live vaccines, including VZV and MMR. The only 4-year-old immunizations this patient should receive are DTaP and IPV.

This patient should also receive hepatitis A vaccine. Two doses of hepatitis A vaccine are needed for lasting protection, but this patient received only one dose, at 12 months of age. A second dose should have been given 6 to 18 months later. She does not need to restart the hepatitis A vaccine series.

B) INCORRECT:

The immunizations typically given at the 4-year-old well-child visit are the fifth dose of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, the fourth dose of the inactivated poliovirus (IPV) vaccine, and the second doses of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) vaccines. However, children receiving chemotherapy are immunosuppressed and should not receive live vaccines, including VZV and MMR. The only 4-year-old immunizations this patient should receive are DTaP and IPV.

This patient should also receive hepatitis A vaccine. Two doses of hepatitis A vaccine are needed for lasting protection, but this patient received only one dose, at 12 months of age. A second dose should have been given 6 to 18 months later. She does not need to restart the hepatitis A vaccine series.

C) INCORRECT:

The immunizations typically given at the 4-year-old well-child visit are the fifth dose of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, the fourth dose of the inactivated poliovirus (IPV) vaccine, and the second doses of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) vaccines. However, children receiving chemotherapy are immunosuppressed and should not receive live vaccines, including VZV and MMR. The only 4-year-old immunizations this patient should receive are DTaP and IPV. This patient should also receive hepatitis A vaccine. Two doses of hepatitis A vaccine are needed for lasting protection, but this patient received only one dose, at 12 months of age.

D) CORRECT:

This child is up to date on her immunizations with the exception of her second hepatitis A vaccine and her 4-year vaccines.

The immunizations typically given at the 4-year-old well-child visit are the fifth dose of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, the fourth dose of the inactivated poliovirus (IPV) vaccine, and the second doses of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) vaccines. However, children receiving chemotherapy are immunosuppressed and should not receive live vaccines, including VZV and MMR. The only 4-year-old immunizations this patient should receive are DTaP and IPV.

This patient should also receive hepatitis A vaccine. Two doses of hepatitis A vaccine are needed for lasting protection, but this patient received only one dose, at 12 months of age. A second dose should have been given 6 to 18 months later. She does not need to restart the hepatitis A vaccine series.

If influenza vaccine is available, she should also receive trivalent inactivated influenza vaccine at this visit.

Key learning point: Patients who are immunosuppressed (e.g., those with cancer and those receiving cancer treatments or glucocorticoids) should not receive live vaccines, such as varicella-zoster virus or measles-mumps-rubella vaccines.

E) INCORRECT:

Children receiving chemotherapy are immunosuppressed and should not receive live vaccines, including VZV and MMR.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl presents for a well-child visit accompanied by her mother. When you discuss the immunizations scheduled for this visit, the mother voices concern about the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, citing an article she read about two young women who died of blood clots shortly after receiving the vaccine. She asks your advice on how to proceed.
Which one of the following statements is most appropriate to share with this patient and her mother?

choices.text: Millions of children have received the HPV vaccine, but only a few have developed blood clots. Therefore, the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the increased risk of blood clots.
Most cases of blood clots after HPV vaccination were among women taking oral contraceptives. Patients who are not taking oral contraceptives do not need to worry about this risk.
The best course of action is to avoid the HPV vaccine but start screening for cervical cancer at age 21 to 25.
Although the risk of a blood clot after HPV vaccination is low, we can reduce this risk even further by staggering the administration of the vaccine doses.
Prospective studies conducted before and after vaccine licensure show that the risk of blood clots does not differ between children who received the HPV vaccine and those who did not.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given these safety data, there is no reason to suggest avoiding the HPV vaccine or to offer an alternate vaccination schedule. If parents express reluctance about the vaccine, it is best to explain that you understand their concerns, that you also want the best for their children, and that there is no evidence of a link between HPV vaccination and VTE risk (or any other major adverse event).

B) INCORRECT:

In terms of the HPV vaccine, VAERS did detect several cases of venous thromboembolism (VTE) after HPV vaccination. However, postlicensure prospective cohort studies conducted through the VSD have found no difference in VTE risk between individuals who received the quadrivalent HPV vaccine and those who did not. Additional studies have shown similar results specifically among women taking oral contraceptives and among girls aged 10 to 17. The randomized controlled trials leading to licensure of the 9-valent HPV vaccine also showed no evidence of increased VTE risk among vaccinated women.

C) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines around cervical cancer screening are evolving but generally recommend initiation at either age 21 or age 25. Such screening does not take the place of receiving the HPV vaccine now.

D) INCORRECT:

Given these safety data, there is no reason to suggest avoiding the HPV vaccine or to offer an alternate vaccination schedule.

E) CORRECT:

In addition to being rigorously evaluated in prelicensure randomized controlled trials, vaccine safety is continuously and active scrutinized after licensure. The two principal methods for this in the United States are the Vaccine Adverse Events Reporting System (VAERS) and the Vaccine Safety Datalink (VSD).

With VAERS, any clinician, patient, or parent can report an adverse event that occurred after vaccination. Scientists continuously review these reports (around 30,000 each year) to identify possible safety concerns (called “signals”) with vaccines. Because the system relies entirely on case reports, it can be used to generate hypotheses about vaccine safety (and can be an early warning system for rare events), but it cannot determine whether a particular vaccine causes a particular event; for this, additional study is needed — and that research is often conducted within the VSD.

The VSD collects electronic health data from nine health care organizations across the country. When a signal is detected through VAERS or a concern about vaccine safety is raised in the medical literature, the VSD conducts vaccine safety studies to determine if the signal represents a true adverse effect of the vaccine. Because the VSD collects a large volume of data from both vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals, it can reliably validate or discard information that is generated through case reports alone.

Key learning point: Postlicensure prospective cohort studies have found that the risk for venous thromboembolism among children receiving the HPV vaccine is similar to that of children who have not received the vaccine.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for a well-child examination. He has cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening. His parents report frequent feedings and large-volume, greasy stools. Current medications include bronchodilators, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and fat-soluble vitamins. He is at the 18th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Auscultation of the lungs discloses diffuse wheezes. Examination shows a distended and tympanic abdomen with no tenderness or guarding. Which of the following would be a contraindication for administering one or more routine vaccinations in this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developing a fever after vaccination is not a contraindication for subsequent vaccinations. Although developing a fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving DTaP was previously a contraindication for subsequent DTaP vaccinations, it is now considered safe to administer the vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever at the time of vaccination, is a precaution rather than a contraindication for most vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis is not a contraindication for any vaccines. If possible, patients with cystic fibrosis should always be up-to-date with their vaccinations to prevent complications.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of severe allergic reaction (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or any of its components is a contraindication for any particular vaccine. However, a history of egg protein allergy without severe reaction to a vaccine is not a contraindication for egg protein-containing vaccines (e.g., flu vaccine) according to the Centers for Disease Control. Moreover, none of the routine immunizations scheduled at 4 months (rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV) contain egg proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain unstable neurological disorders (e.g., uncontrolled epilepsy, infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy) are contraindications for the pertussis vaccine, which is part of the DTaP vaccine. However, niether stable neurological disorders (e.g., controlled epilepsy), nor resolved neurological disorders, nor a history of uncomplicated febrile seizures are contraindications for any of the standard childhood vaccines.

E) CORRECT:

Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing intussusception. Although data is conflicting, a history of intussusception is considered a contraindication for receiving the rotavirus vaccine according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC). The exact mechanism by which the rotavirus vaccine leads to intussusception is unknown. Some studies suggest that since the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine the overall incidence of intussusception has not risen but the average age of onset in infants has decreased.

According to the CDC, other contraindications to the rotavirus vaccine are severe combined immunodeficiency and severe allergic reactions (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine.
questions.hint: This 4-month-old patient should receive his routine immunizations, including diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), pneumococcal conjugate, and rotavirus vaccines, the latter of which is contraindicated by one of the conditions listed below.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is due for her second MMR vaccine. Her medical record notes that she has developed a generalized rash following egg ingestion and localized rash after applying topical bacitracin-neomycin-polymixin ointment. Medical history is remarkable for two simple febrile seizures at ages 15 months and 18 months. Her father is currently receiving chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma. What is the most appropriate MMR vaccination strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Delay the vaccine until the egg allergy can be evaluated by an allergist
Delay the vaccine until the child has been seizure-free for 5 years
Delay the vaccine until the child's father has completed chemotherapy
Inform the child's parents that she should not receive the vaccine because of her possible neomycin allergy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Egg allergy is also not a contraindication; the MMR vaccine does not contain significant amounts of egg-white cross-reacting proteins. Furthermore, this child received her first dose of MMR without incident, making it very unlikely that she will have an adverse event now.

B) INCORRECT:

Children with a personal history of seizures or a family history (in a first-degree relative such as a sibling or a parent) may be at slightly increased risk for seizures after MMR vaccine administration, but they should still be immunized because the benefits outweigh the risks. In this patient with a history of febrile seizures, the benefits of immunizations definitely outweigh the risks.

C) INCORRECT:

Severely immunocompromised patients should not receive the MMR vaccine. However, there is no contraindication in individuals whose family members are immunocompromised because the viruses contained in the MMR vaccine are not shed after immunization.

D) CORRECT:

Children with a personal history of seizures or a family history (in a first-degree relative such as a sibling or a parent) may be at slightly increased risk for seizures after MMR vaccine administration, but they should still be immunized because the benefits outweigh the risks. In this patient with a history of febrile seizures, the benefits of immunizations outweigh the risks.

Neomycin allergy that manifests as contact dermatitis is not a contraindication to vaccination. People who have experienced anaphylaxis due to neomycin or gelatin should receive the MMR vaccine only in consultation with an allergist and in a setting where a life-threatening reaction could be managed.

Egg allergy is also not a contraindication; the MMR vaccine does not contain significant amounts of egg-white cross-reacting proteins. Furthermore, this child received her first dose of MMR without incident, making it very unlikely that she will have an adverse event now.

Severely immunocompromised patients should not receive the MMR vaccine. However, there is no contraindication in individuals whose family members are immunocompromised, because the viruses contained in the MMR vaccine are not shed after immunization.

An alternative MMR immunization that includes the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) vaccine is also an option for children aged 1 to 12 years who require both MMR and VZV vaccination. However, this four-component vaccine has been associated with a small increase in febrile seizures and may not be optimal for this child, given her history of febrile seizures.

Key learning point: Contraindications to measles-mumps-rubella vaccination include severe hypersensitivity to neomycin or gelatin, severe immunosuppression due to chemotherapy or congenital immunodeficiency, and pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Neomycin allergy that manifests as contact dermatitis is not a contraindication to vaccination. People who have experienced anaphylaxis due to neomycin or gelatin should receive the MMR vaccine only in consultation with an allergist and in a setting where a life-threatening reaction could be managed.
questions.hint: The measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine series is given in two doses, with the second dose intended to cover the roughly 5% of children who do not respond to the first dose. The first dose should be given at 12 to 15 months of age (preferably at 12 months) and the second at 4 to 6 years of age.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for a routine check-up. The mother states that she is worried about vaccine side effects and has heard that immunizations might increase the risk of autism. She mentions she has postponed several recommended vaccines. The child's physical exam is unremarkable, and his growth parameters track on the 50th percentile. She remains uncertain about proceeding with vaccination. What is the most appropriate next step in addressing her concerns?

choices.text: Decline to continue medical care unless she consents to all recommended vaccines
Acknowledge her worries and provide clear, evidence-based information addressing vaccine safety
Offer an alternative vaccine schedule to minimize the number of simultaneous injections
Recommend indefinite delaying of immunizations until she feels more comfortable

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Declining care unless all vaccines are accepted disregards the importance of a therapeutic alliance. Engaging with vaccine-hesitant parents through respectful dialogue and evidence-based information is crucial. Discontinuing care may reduce access to health services and compromise the child's well-being.

B) CORRECT:

Parental concerns about vaccine safety, particularly regarding autism, require empathetic and evidence-based communication. Acknowledging the parent's worries builds trust, while providing data from extensive research reassures them of vaccine safety and the lack of a causal link to autism. This approach emphasizes the benefits of the standard vaccine schedule and addresses safety concerns through transparent communication, helping parents make informed decisions that protect individual and public health.

Key learning point: When encountering vaccine hesitancy, healthcare providers should engage in open communication and provide education about the importance and benefits of immunization to address concerns and promote public health.

C) INCORRECT:

Offering an alternative vaccine schedule is not supported by evidence-based guidelines. The recommended schedule ensures timely protection against diseases. Altering it can delay immunity and leave the child susceptible to infections. Studies show multiple vaccines do not overburden the immune system or increase autism risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Indefinitely delaying immunizations increases the risk of vaccine-preventable diseases and does not address the unfounded fear of autism. Timely immunization schedules provide optimal protection, and postponing vaccines may reinforce misinformation and leave the child vulnerable during critical periods of susceptibility.

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a routine well-child visit. Her parents express reluctance to follow the recommended immunization schedule, citing concerns about side effects and online reports linking vaccines to developmental disorders. They request to delay or omit several vaccines. Physical examination of the infant is unremarkable, with normal growth parameters. They ask how you suggest proceeding with her immunizations.

choices.text: Insist on administering all vaccines immediately or refuse future care for the infant
Agree to postpone immunizations indefinitely until they feel comfortable
Address concerns individually, correct misinformation, and explain the proven safety and benefits of recommended vaccines
Advise obtaining information from non-peer-reviewed websites before deciding

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Strict adherence to immunization schedules without addressing parental concerns overlooks the importance of empathy and evidence-based information. Enforcing immediate vaccination or threatening to terminate care ignores the need for shared decision-making and trust-building. Dismissing or refusing care can compromise the therapeutic relationship and worsen vaccine hesitancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Deferring immunizations indefinitely exposes the infant to preventable diseases and disrupts the protective timeline established by public health protocols. Delaying immunizations neglects the robust data supporting vaccine safety and efficacy and compromises the infant’s timely acquisition of protective immunity.

C) CORRECT:

Effective communication with parents about vaccination involves a respectful, individualized discussion that acknowledges their concerns and provides clear, evidence-based information. Engaging in dialogue that explains how vaccines are rigorously tested and continuously monitored for safety can help counteract misinformation. Detailing how the immunization schedule is designed to protect infants from severe, potentially life-threatening diseases reinforces the benefits of early vaccination. This approach supports informed decision-making while emphasizing both individual protection and broader public health through herd immunity.

Key learning point: When parents express concerns about vaccinations due to misinformation, healthcare providers should engage in respectful dialogue to correct myths and explain the benefits of vaccinations to ensure informed decision-making.

D) INCORRECT:

Recommending non-peer-reviewed websites for vaccine information is problematic, as these sources often lack rigorous evaluation and may propagate misinformation. Guiding families to evidence-based resources ensures they receive accurate information, which is critical when addressing vaccine hesitancy.

questions.text:
A 14-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for scheduled immunizations. He has a history of repeated severe otitis media and pneumonia requiring multiple antibiotic courses. A maternal cousin has a primary immunodeficiency. He is in the 10th percentile for weight. The mother is concerned about the varicella vaccine.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this patient’s varicella vaccination?

choices.text: Initiate monthly intravenous immunoglobulin and avoid varicella vaccination
Proceed with varicella vaccination according to the current schedule
Provide prophylactic acyclovir and administer the varicella vaccine in one week
Obtain immunologic evaluations before administering the live vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monthly intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is reserved for confirmed severe immunodeficiencies. Although the patient's history suggests possible immunodeficiency, there is no definitive evidence of severe antibody deficiency requiring IVIG. Family history alone, especially involving a cousin, does not contraindicate routine immunizations without further evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

While the varicella vaccine is routinely administered to immunocompetent children between 12 and 15 months, this patient’s history of severe infections and family history of immunodeficiency raises suspicion of an underlying immune disorder. In such cases, live vaccines can pose a risk of uncontrolled infection due to impaired immune responses, necessitating an immunologic evaluation before vaccination.

C) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic acyclovir is not used to mitigate risks associated with live vaccine administration in potential immunodeficiency. Acyclovir treats active varicella infections but does not ensure safety against vaccine-related complications in immunocompromised patients. An immunologic evaluation is necessary before administering live vaccines.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's recurrent severe infections, failure to thrive, and family history of immunodeficiency suggest a possible underlying immunocompromised state. Live-attenuated vaccines, like the varicella vaccine, require a competent immune system to control viral replication. In immunocompromised patients, there is a risk of uncontrolled viral replication and disseminated infection. An immunologic evaluation, including assessments of T-cell function and immunoglobulin levels, is crucial to determine the patient's immune competence and guide safe vaccination practices.

Key learning point: In patients with suspected immunodeficiency, live vaccines such as the varicella vaccine should be avoided until the immune status is assessed.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant develops mild redness and swelling at the injection site after DTP immunization. She is afebrile and feeding normally. Which minor adverse effect of DTP vaccination is most common?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Injection site erythema is a common local reaction to the DTP vaccine, resulting from an inflammatory response to the antigen or adjuvant. This reaction involves cytokine release and immune cell recruitment, causing redness and mild swelling. It is the most frequent minor adverse effect of DTP immunization, typically resolving without intervention and indicating the vaccine's immunogenicity.

Key learning point: Injection site erythema is the most common minor side effect of the DTP vaccination.

B) INCORRECT:

Mild local lymphadenopathy can occur due to immune activation by vaccines, but it is not the most common minor adverse effect of DTP immunization. The infant's presentation of mild redness and swelling at the injection site aligns more with typical local reactions than with lymphadenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent crying for more than 3 hours is a less common systemic reaction to the DTP vaccine, often linked to the pertussis component. The infant's mild localized reaction and normal behavior suggest a typical local response rather than prolonged systemic distress.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypotonic hyporesponsive episodes (HHE) are rare adverse reactions to pertussis-containing vaccines, characterized by decreased muscle tone and reduced responsiveness. The infant's mild redness and swelling without systemic symptoms indicate a common local reaction, not HHE.

questions.text:
A 15-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother after developing mild redness, swelling, and low-grade fever the day after a routine immunization. These symptoms resolved without treatment in two days. She is concerned about potential severe reactions and asks if these mild local reactions suggest a higher likelihood of serious complications and whether further vaccinations should be postponed.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Defer all subsequent vaccinations for six months
Provide reassurance and continue recommended immunizations
Prescribe prophylactic antibiotics prior to each injection
Refer for allergy testing before proceeding with future doses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mild local reactions are common and do not predict severe adverse events. Delaying vaccinations would unnecessarily expose the child to vaccine-preventable diseases. Current guidelines support continuing the vaccination schedule in the absence of severe contraindications.

B) CORRECT:

Minor local reactions, such as redness, swelling, and low-grade fever, are common after immunizations and indicate an appropriate immune response. These transient symptoms do not suggest a higher risk of severe complications. Continuing the vaccination schedule is crucial to protect against vaccine-preventable diseases. Reassurance about the benign nature of these reactions helps maintain vaccination compliance and public confidence in immunization programs.

Key learning point: Mild local reactions such as fever, redness, and swelling after vaccinations are common and not a contraindication to future vaccinations; reassurance should be provided to caregivers.

C) INCORRECT:

Mild local reactions after immunizations are expected and not indicative of an infection requiring antibiotics. These reactions resolve spontaneously and do not necessitate antibiotic prophylaxis, which could lead to unnecessary risks like antibiotic resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

The mild redness, swelling, and low-grade fever described are typical local inflammatory responses, not immediate allergic reactions. True allergic reactions occur rapidly and involve symptoms like urticaria or anaphylaxis. Allergy testing is not indicated for mild, delayed reactions.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a routine checkup. She has had watery diarrhea for two days but remains playful and well-hydrated. There is no fever, vomiting, or evidence of severe illness. Her immunizations are current. Her mother is concerned that the diarrhea might interfere with today's scheduled vaccines.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain stool culture and re-evaluate in one week
Defer immunizations until her diarrhea completely resolves
Administer only partial vaccinations until symptoms subside

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild acute illnesses, such as watery diarrhea in an otherwise healthy 8-month-old, are not contraindications to routine immunization. Guidelines from the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommend that children with mild symptoms, including low-grade illness or isolated gastrointestinal symptoms, should receive their scheduled vaccines. The immune response to vaccination is not significantly altered by minor illnesses, and delaying immunizations increases the risk of vaccine-preventable diseases. The child's stable hydration and absence of systemic symptoms indicate that proceeding with immunizations is safe and beneficial.

Key learning point: Mild acute illness, such as diarrhea without severe symptoms, is not a contraindication to routine vaccination in infants.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a stool culture is unnecessary in an infant with mild, brief diarrhea without fever or systemic symptoms. A viral etiology is more likely, and bacterial workup is not indicated. Mild, non-systemic illnesses are not contraindications to vaccination, and delaying care for a stool culture introduces unnecessary postponement of routine preventive measures.

C) INCORRECT:

Deferring immunizations due to mild illnesses, such as watery diarrhea, is not supported by current guidelines. The infant's well-hydrated status, absence of fever, and playful demeanor indicate that her immune system is not compromised. The benefits of adhering to the vaccination schedule outweigh the unfounded risks of concurrent mild illnesses.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering partial vaccinations due to mild illness is not recommended. In a well-appearing, hydrated infant without systemic signs of illness, guidelines support administering all scheduled vaccines. Mild illnesses do not significantly impair the immune response to vaccination, and partial vaccination risks delaying complete protection against serious illnesses.

questions.text:
A 14-month-old boy is brought to the office by his mother after experiencing a 1-minute generalized convulsion with a fever of 38.9°C yesterday. The episode resolved spontaneously. He received a routine vaccine two days prior. He is now active and alert with normal examination findings. The mother is concerned about future immunizations.

Temperature
38.9°C

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic anticonvulsants are not indicated for simple febrile seizures, which are brief and self-limited. Anticonvulsants are reserved for complex febrile seizures or epilepsy syndromes due to their potential side effects. The child's seizure was brief, and he returned to normal neurological status.

B) INCORRECT:

A simple febrile seizure, even if occurring after immunization, does not indicate an underlying neurological disorder and is not a contraindication to continuing vaccinations. Delaying vaccinations exposes the child to risks of vaccine-preventable diseases. The seizure was likely triggered by fever, not the vaccine itself.

C) CORRECT:

The child experienced a simple febrile seizure, which is common in children aged 6 months to 5 years and often occurs with mild fever from infection or immunization. These seizures are brief, generalized, and not linked to increased epilepsy risk. Vaccine-induced fevers can trigger febrile seizures, but this does not necessitate altering the immunization schedule. The benefits of vaccination in preventing serious diseases outweigh the transient risk of fever. Parents should be reassured about the excellent prognosis of febrile seizures and the importance of continuing routine immunizations.

Key learning point: Febrile seizures are not a contraindication for future vaccinations, and children should continue to receive vaccines according to the recommended schedule.

D) INCORRECT:

An EEG is not necessary for simple febrile seizures, which are brief and occur with fever. EEGs are reserved for complex seizures or when there are focal features or persistent neurological abnormalities. Simple febrile seizures are benign and do not require extensive workup.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the Pediatrician for a routine check-up. He has had a mild runny nose and occasional cough for the past few days but no significant fever. Physical examination reveals a mildly congested nasal passage. He is due for immunizations today, but the mother is concerned about administering them while he is slightly ill.
What is the most appropriate next step regarding his vaccines?

choices.text: Obtain a complete blood count prior to vaccination
Postpone vaccination until he is asymptomatic for 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mild illnesses, such as a runny nose or occasional cough, do not impair the immune response to vaccines and are not contraindications to immunization. Studies show that the effectiveness and safety of vaccines remain intact with minor symptoms. Current guidelines recommend continuing the routine immunization schedule even with a low-grade upper respiratory infection, as delaying vaccination can postpone protection against serious diseases. The immune activation from the vaccine is not diminished by mild illness, ensuring the infant achieves the expected immunologic benefit.

Key learning point: Mild illnesses, such as a low-grade fever, are not contraindications to vaccination, and it is important to keep infants on schedule with their immunizations.

B) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count (CBC) is unnecessary for mild upper respiratory symptoms without significant systemic symptoms or fever. Mild illnesses are not contraindications to routine immunizations, and guidelines recommend proceeding with vaccination. A CBC is reserved for suspected serious infections or conditions impairing immune response, neither of which is suggested by the child's stable examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Minor acute illnesses, such as a runny nose and occasional cough without significant fever, are not contraindications to vaccination. The immune response to vaccines remains effective in mild illnesses. Administering vaccines on schedule maintains timely protection against preventable diseases. The child's minor symptoms do not interfere with immunogenicity or increase adverse reaction risk, so postponing is not supported by current guidelines.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine pre-vaccination administration of antipyretics can reduce antibody responses to certain vaccine antigens, potentially impacting efficacy. In an infant with mild symptoms, such as a runny nose and occasional cough, the illness does not contraindicate vaccines. Guidelines recommend proceeding with immunizations during mild illnesses and using acetaminophen for post-vaccination symptoms if needed.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is in the Outpatient Clinic for routine immunizations. He has mild otitis media and has completed three days of oral amoxicillin with improvement. His mother reports a mild cough persisting for a week, but he has no fever and is active and well otherwise. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination is noncontributory. The mother is concerned that antibiotic therapy and the mild cough may delay vaccination.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Postpone immunization until the child is symptom-free for at least one week
Delay vaccination until the antibiotic course is completed
Obtain chest imaging before administering immunizations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The child has only a mild cough and is otherwise well, which does not warrant delaying immunization. Mild illnesses are not contraindications for vaccination. Minor viral symptoms, without fever or systemic signs, do not compromise vaccine safety or efficacy. Immunizing during minor illnesses maintains protection without affecting the immune response.

B) INCORRECT:

Mild infections or the use of common antibiotics do not contraindicate immunization. The child's mild cough and recent amoxicillin course for resolving otitis media do not indicate a moderate or severe illness. Antibiotic therapy does not interfere with vaccine efficacy, and delaying immunization unnecessarily prolongs vulnerability to vaccine-preventable diseases.

C) CORRECT:

Current immunization guidelines indicate that minor illnesses, such as a mild cough or partially treated otitis media, do not contraindicate vaccination. Antibiotic use does not interfere with the immune response to vaccines. Administering vaccines on schedule ensures timely protection against vaccine-preventable diseases and reduces the risk of missed opportunities. As long as the child is not experiencing moderate to severe illness, immunizations should proceed as planned.

Key learning point: Mild illnesses and antibiotic use are not contraindications to vaccination, and children can be vaccinated as per schedule even if they are on antibiotics for a mild illness.

D) INCORRECT:

The child's mild cough, without fever or abnormal examination findings, makes significant lower respiratory tract infection unlikely. Chest imaging is reserved for concerns like pneumonia, indicated by tachypnea, abnormal lung sounds, or high fever, which are absent here. Mild viral illnesses or resolving infections do not warrant imaging before vaccination.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is hospitalized with hemolytic anemia secondary to hereditary spherocytosis. He received two units of packed red blood cells three weeks ago. His vaccination record shows he is due for the second dose of an inactivated hepatitis A vaccine. His mother is concerned about whether the recent transfusion affects his scheduled immunizations. Physical examination is normal, and laboratory values have stabilized. Vital signs are unchanged from baseline. He is not currently on any medications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Use passive immunoglobulin in place of immunization
Obtain baseline antibody titers before vaccination
Postpone vaccination for at least three months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Passive immunoglobulin provides temporary protection and is used for rapid prophylaxis, not routine immunizations. The inactivated hepatitis A vaccine is not affected by passive antibodies, and active immunization is preferred for long-term immunity.

B) CORRECT:

Inactivated vaccines, such as the hepatitis A vaccine, are unaffected by passively acquired antibodies from blood transfusions. Packed red blood cells contain minimal residual plasma and antibodies, which do not interfere with the immunogenicity of inactivated vaccines. Immunologic interference is a concern for live vaccines, not inactivated ones. Therefore, inactivated vaccines can be administered on schedule, ensuring timely protection without compromising efficacy.

Key learning point: Inactivated vaccines, such as the hepatitis A vaccine, can be administered as per schedule even after a recent blood transfusion, as passive antibody transfer does not affect their efficacy.

C) INCORRECT:

Baseline antibody titers are unnecessary for inactivated vaccines like the hepatitis A vaccine, as their immunogenicity is not impaired by passive antibodies from transfusions. The patient's stable status supports following the routine immunization schedule.

D) INCORRECT:

Postponing vaccination is unnecessary for inactivated vaccines like the hepatitis A vaccine, as they are not affected by the minimal antibodies present in packed red blood cells. This differs from live vaccines, which may require delay after large doses of immunoglobulin.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to a history of multiple infections, including Pneumocystis pneumonia and severe varicella at seven months of age. Physical examination shows absent lymph nodes and no palpable spleen. Serum immunoglobulin levels are pending confirmatory tests. The mother wishes to follow the recommended vaccination schedule, including live attenuated vaccines, and is concerned about the child's risk for infection.
Which of the following is the best approach to immunizing this patient?

choices.text: Withhold all vaccinations until immunoglobulin studies are completely normal
Administer all indicated inactivated vaccines but postpone live attenuated vaccines until immunodeficiency is ruled out
Administer immunoglobulin therapy before giving any vaccines, including live ones
Begin all standard vaccinations immediately, including live attenuated vaccines

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While abnormal immunoglobulin levels can indicate compromised humoral immunity, the clinical presentation suggests a combined immunodeficiency. Inactivated vaccines are safe and can be administered despite abnormal immunoglobulin levels. Withholding all vaccinations increases the risk of infections that could be prevented by inactivated vaccines.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's history of opportunistic infections, absent lymph nodes, and non-palpable spleen suggests a combined immunodeficiency, potentially affecting T-cell and B-cell function. Live attenuated vaccines pose a risk of causing disease in immunocompromised individuals due to their replication-competent organisms. In contrast, inactivated vaccines do not contain live pathogens and are safe for patients with immunodeficiencies. Therefore, the appropriate approach is to administer inactivated vaccines while deferring live vaccines until immunodeficiency is ruled out through confirmatory testing.

Key learning point: In children suspected of having an immunodeficiency, live vaccines should be avoided due to the risk of causing disease in an immunocompromised host.

C) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin therapy provides passive immunity but does not make live attenuated vaccines safe for immunocompromised patients. In a child with suspected severe immunodeficiency, live vaccines remain contraindicated due to the risk of disseminated infections. Immunoglobulin therapy does not induce immunologic memory or modify the contraindication to live vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering live attenuated vaccines to a child with suspected immunodeficiency, such as severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), can lead to severe or disseminated infections due to uncontrolled replication of vaccine-derived organisms. The patient's history of opportunistic infections and absent lymph nodes suggests an underlying immunodeficiency, necessitating caution with live vaccines.

questions.text: A 28-year-old traveler with severe egg allergy needs yellow fever vaccination for an upcoming trip. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Give vaccine with prophylactic corticosteroids and antihistamines
Refer to an allergy specialist for assessment before vaccination
Proceed with standard vaccination in an outpatient clinic
Advise strict avoidance of vaccination and rely solely on mosquito precautions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Premedicating with corticosteroids and antihistamines does not prevent the immediate IgE-mediated reactions responsible for anaphylaxis. Corticosteroids act slowly, and antihistamines do not block all mediators of anaphylaxis. Structured evaluation and controlled administration are necessary for safe vaccination.

B) CORRECT:

The yellow fever vaccine contains egg proteins due to its production in embryonated chicken eggs, posing a risk of anaphylaxis in individuals with severe egg allergy. Referral to an allergy specialist allows for a detailed evaluation, including potential skin testing or a graded vaccine challenge, in a controlled environment. This ensures that if vaccination proceeds, it occurs in a setting equipped to manage severe allergic reactions, balancing the vaccine's benefits with patient safety.

Key learning point: The yellow fever vaccine is contraindicated in individuals with severe egg allergy and should be assessed by an allergy/immunology specialist before administration.

C) INCORRECT:

Standard vaccination in an outpatient clinic is inappropriate for individuals with severe egg allergy due to the risk of anaphylaxis from egg proteins in the yellow fever vaccine. Outpatient clinics may lack the resources to manage severe allergic reactions, necessitating vaccination in a controlled setting.

D) INCORRECT:

Relying solely on mosquito precautions is insufficient in regions where yellow fever is endemic. Vaccination is the primary prevention method, and protocols exist for safe administration in individuals with severe egg allergy, such as supervised administration or graded dosing.

questions.text: A 2-year-old developed seizures and prolonged confusion within 5 days of her third DTaP dose. She has fully recovered. What is the most appropriate next step for immunization?

choices.text: Continue with DT for future doses

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Severe neurological reactions, such as seizures with prolonged confusion within 7 days of a DTaP dose, contraindicate the pertussis component in future immunizations. This reaction suggests an encephalopathic response to the pertussis antigen, not the diphtheria or tetanus components. Administering a diphtheria and tetanus (DT) vaccine maintains protection against these infections while avoiding the pertussis antigen. Clinical guidelines recommend substituting DT in individuals with such serious neurological complications, ensuring continued immunization without recurrent neurologic risk.

Key learning point: Encephalopathy within 7 days of a previous DTaP dose is an absolute contraindication to further DTaP vaccination.

B) INCORRECT:

The child's seizures and prolonged confusion after the DTaP dose indicate a serious neurologic adverse event, contraindicating further pertussis-containing vaccines. Continuing with routine DTaP risks re-exposing the child to the pertussis component likely responsible for the reaction. Guidelines recommend using vaccines without the pertussis component in such cases.

C) INCORRECT:

Reducing the DTaP dose does not mitigate the risk of neurologic reactions, which are not dose-dependent but reflect an abnormal immune response to the pertussis component. A half dose may compromise immunogenicity without preventing adverse events. Current protocols do not support dosing modifications for neurologic adverse events.

D) INCORRECT:

Delaying immunizations for six months is unnecessary, as the child has fully recovered from the acute adverse reaction. The severe neurologic reaction is linked to the pertussis component, not an underlying condition. Immunization guidelines recommend using a pertussis-free formulation, such as DT, rather than delaying all vaccinations.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman with moderate-to-severe systemic lupus erythematosus presents to the Outpatient Clinic. She has been receiving high-dose prednisolone and mycophenolate mofetil for six months. She is up to date on her routine immunizations and is concerned about influenza during the upcoming winter season. Her most recent laboratory results show stable blood counts without active infection.
Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination for her at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The measles-mumps-rubella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, which requires a competent immune system to prevent uncontrolled viral replication. In patients on high-dose immunosuppressive therapy, there is an increased risk of infection from the vaccine strains. Additionally, the patient is likely already vaccinated against MMR, reducing the need for re-administration.

B) INCORRECT:

The intranasal live-attenuated influenza vaccine contains weakened viruses that require an intact immune system to prevent infection. In patients with significant immunosuppression, such as those on high-dose prednisolone and mycophenolate mofetil, there is a risk of viral replication and inadequate immune response. Therefore, live vaccines are contraindicated in immunosuppressed patients.

C) INCORRECT:

The varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, requiring a competent immune system to prevent viral replication. Patients on high-dose corticosteroids and mycophenolate mofetil have significant immunosuppression, increasing the risk of vaccine strain dissemination. Live vaccines are not recommended for patients with marked immunosuppression.

D) CORRECT:

In patients on high-dose immunosuppressive therapy, inactivated vaccines are preferred. The inactivated influenza injection contains viral antigens that stimulate an immune response without the risk of active viral replication. Immunosuppressive agents like prednisolone and mycophenolate mofetil compromise immune defenses, so using a non-replicating vaccine formulation minimizes complications. The influenza vaccine reduces the severity and incidence of influenza in vulnerable populations, including those with autoimmune conditions on immunosuppressive treatment.

Key learning point: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus on high-dose immunosuppressive therapy, live vaccines are contraindicated, but inactivated vaccines like the annual influenza vaccine are recommended.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old boy in the emergency department who presents with a 1-day history of involuntary muscle contractions and pain in his back and neck. Two weeks ago, he fell while playing in a sandbox and scraped his knees. He has not received any vaccinations since birth. His temperature is 38.5°C. He is diaphoretic. On examination, he is unable to open his mouth beyond 1 cm, has hyperextension of the lumbar spine, and shows resistance to neck flexion. Which one of the following, if administered, would most likely have prevented his current condition?

choices.text: Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Denatured C. tetani toxoid is used as a vaccination against tetanus. The still-intact receptor binding site of the toxoid induces antibody production and memory cell formation (active immunity). In patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, postexposure prophylaxis should include vaccination with DTaP and administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (HTIG). Management of tetanus includes antibiotic therapy and intensive care treatment.

Key learning point: The tetanus vaccine is a denatured (inactivated) bacterial toxoid that induces active immunity and prevents tetanus infection.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Capsular polysaccharide vaccines contain purified capsule antigens that are usually conjugated to a carrier protein (conjugate vaccine). Such vaccines are used to prevent infection with, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and N. meningitidis, all of which can cause meningitis. Although meningitis can present with fever and neck stiffness, trismus and opisthotonus are not characteristic features. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

C) INCORRECT:

Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of rabies. Administering preformed antibodies provides a passive immunity that, however, does not last long due to the antibodies' short half-life. Even though patients with rabies can present with trismus, opisthotonus, and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity, as seen in this patient, they also present with other characteristic features like hydrophobia and agitation. Furthermore, this patient has no history of an animal bite (e.g., by a bat or raccoon) that would raise suspicion for transmission of rabies. In post-exposure prophylaxis of tetanus, which is caused by a bacterium, not a virus, human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used against tetanus toxin.

D) INCORRECT:

Chemically-inactivated (whole-cell) viruses have been used as vaccines to prevent, e.g., polio (Salk vaccine), hepatitis A, and influenza virus infections. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

E) INCORRECT:

Viable but weakened microorganisms are used in live attenuated vaccines for the prevention of, e.g., measles, mumps, rubella, varicella zoster, and rotavirus infection. These vaccines induce both cellular and humoral immune responses. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.
questions.hint: Generalized muscle spasms (trismus, mild opisthotonus, nuchal rigidity) and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity (fever, sweating) following a cutaneous injury in an unvaccinated child suggest tetanus, which is diagnosed clinically.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-month-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. He has cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening. His parents report that he feeds frequently and has large-volume, greasy stools. His current medications include bronchodilators, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and fat-soluble vitamins. His height is at the 18th percentile and his weight is at the 15th percentile. On lung auscultation, there are diffuse wheezes. Abdominal examination reveals a distended and tympanic abdomen without tenderness or guarding. Which one of the following would be a contraindication to administering one or more routine vaccinations to this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developing a fever after vaccination is not a contraindication for subsequent vaccinations. Although developing a fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving DTaP was previously a contraindication for subsequent DTaP vaccinations, it is now considered safe to administer the vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever at the time of vaccination, is a precaution rather than a contraindication for most vaccines.

B) CORRECT:

Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing intussusception. Although data is conflicting, a history of intussusception is considered a contraindication for receiving the rotavirus vaccine according to the National Advisory Committee on Immunization. The exact mechanism by which the rotavirus vaccine leads to intussusception is unknown. Some studies suggest that since the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine the overall incidence of intussusception has not risen but the average age of onset in infants has decreased.

Other contraindications to the rotavirus vaccine are severe combined immunodeficiency and severe allergic reactions (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine.

Key learning point: A history of intussusception is a contraindication to administering the rotavirus vaccine in infants.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain unstable neurological disorders (e.g., uncontrolled epilepsy, infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy) are contraindications for the pertussis vaccine, which is part of the DTaP vaccine. However, niether stable neurological disorders (e.g., controlled epilepsy), nor resolved neurological disorders, nor a history of uncomplicated febrile seizures are contraindications for any of the standard childhood vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of severe allergic reaction (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or any of its components is a contraindication for any particular vaccine. However, a history of egg protein allergy without severe reaction to a vaccine is not a contraindication for egg protein-containing vaccines (e.g., flu vaccine) according to the National Advisory Committee on Immunization. Moreover, none of the routine immunizations scheduled at 4 months (rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV) contain egg proteins.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis is not a contraindication for any vaccines. If possible, patients with cystic fibrosis should always be up-to-date with their vaccinations to prevent complications.
questions.hint: This 4-month-old patient should receive his routine immunizations, including diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), pneumococcal conjugate, and rotavirus vaccines, the latter of which is contraindicated by one of the conditions listed below.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old girl who is due for her second MMR vaccine. Her medical record indicates that she developed a generalized rash after eating eggs and a localized rash after using topical bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin ointment. Her history includes two simple febrile seizures at 15 and 18 months of age. Her father is currently undergoing chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma. Which one of the following is the most appropriate MMR vaccination strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Delay the vaccine until the child has been seizure-free for 5 years.
Delay the vaccine until the child's father has completed chemotherapy.
Inform the child's parents that she should not receive the vaccine because of her possible neomycin allergy.
Delay the vaccine until the egg allergy can be evaluated by an allergist.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Children with a personal history of seizures or a family history (in a first-degree relative such as a sibling or a parent) may be at slightly increased risk for seizures after MMR vaccine administration, but they should still be immunized because the benefits outweigh the risks. In this patient with a history of febrile seizures, the benefits of immunizations definitely outweigh the risks.

B) CORRECT:

Children with a personal history of seizures or a family history (in a first-degree relative such as a sibling or a parent) may be at slightly increased risk for seizures after MMR vaccine administration, but they should still be immunized because the benefits outweigh the risks. In this patient with a history of febrile seizures, the benefits of immunizations outweigh the risks. Neomycin allergy that manifests as contact dermatitis is not a contraindication to vaccination. People who have experienced anaphylaxis due to neomycin or gelatin should receive the MMR vaccine only in consultation with an allergist and in a setting where a life-threatening reaction could be managed. Egg allergy is also not a contraindication; the MMR vaccine does not contain significant amounts of egg-white cross-reacting proteins. Furthermore, this child received her first dose of MMR without incident, making it very unlikely that she will have an adverse event now.

Severely immunocompromised patients should not receive the MMR vaccine. However, there is no contraindication in individuals whose family members are immunocompromised, because the viruses contained in the MMR vaccine are not shed after immunization.

An alternative MMR immunization that includes the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) vaccine is also an option for children aged 1 to 12 years who require both MMR and VZV vaccination. However, this four-component vaccine has been associated with a small increase in febrile seizures and may not be optimal for this child, given her history of febrile seizures.

Key learning point: Contraindications to measles-mumps-rubella vaccination include immunosuppression, pregnancy, and previous severe adverse reaction (e.g., anaphylaxis) to the vaccine or vaccine component.

C) INCORRECT:

Severely immunocompromised patients should not receive the MMR vaccine. However, there is no contraindication in individuals whose family members are immunocompromised because the viruses contained in the MMR vaccine are not shed after immunization.

D) INCORRECT:

Neomycin allergy that manifests as contact dermatitis is not a contraindication to vaccination. People who have experienced anaphylaxis due to neomycin or gelatin should receive the MMR vaccine only in consultation with an allergist and in a setting where a life-threatening reaction could be managed.

E) INCORRECT:

Egg allergy is not a contraindication; the MMR vaccine does not contain significant amounts of egg-white cross-reacting proteins. Furthermore, this child received her first dose of MMR without incident, making it very unlikely that she will have an adverse event now.
questions.hint: The measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine series is given in two doses, with the second dose intended to cover the roughly 5% of children who do not respond to the first dose. The first dose should be given at 12 to 15 months of age (preferably at 12 months) and the second at 4 to 6 years of age.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is scheduled for routine immunizations, including MMR and varicella, at the Outpatient Clinic. His 10-year-old sister is receiving chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The parents are concerned about potential transmission of the vaccine strains. The boy’s growth and development are appropriate, and his examination is normal. He has no known allergies and no prior adverse reactions to vaccines.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this child?

choices.text: Vaccinate with MMR only, delaying varicella indefinitely
Defer all live vaccines until sister's chemotherapy is completed
Administer inactivated alternatives for measles and varicella
Proceed with MMR and varicella vaccination as scheduled

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delaying varicella vaccination due to concerns about viral shedding is not supported by evidence. Shedding after varicella vaccination is rare and poses minimal risk to immunocompromised contacts. Delaying vaccination increases the risk of wild-type varicella infection, which is more dangerous, especially in households with immunocompromised individuals.

B) INCORRECT:

Deferring live vaccines due to concerns about transmission to an immunocompromised sibling is unnecessary. The attenuated strains in MMR and varicella vaccines have minimal shedding and transmission risk. Healthy children can safely receive these vaccines, which also protect against wild-type infections that pose a greater risk to immunocompromised contacts.

C) INCORRECT:

Inactivated alternatives for measles and varicella do not exist. MMR and varicella vaccines are live attenuated, providing strong immunity with a low risk of transmission to immunocompromised contacts. Suggesting inactivated alternatives implies non-existent vaccines and does not align with current immunization guidelines.

D) CORRECT:

Live attenuated vaccines, such as MMR and varicella, are safe for household contacts of immunocompromised individuals. The risk of transmission of vaccine-strain viruses from a vaccinated healthy child is extremely low. These vaccines induce immunity without causing disease in immunocompetent recipients. Administering these vaccines protects the child and indirectly reduces the risk of wild-type infections in the immunocompromised sibling. Current guidelines support routine vaccination for household contacts of immunocompromised patients.

Key learning point: Live attenuated vaccines, such as varicella and MMR, should not be avoided in households with immunocompromised individuals, as the risk of vaccine-derived infection transmission is extremely low.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of involuntary muscle contractions and pain in his back and neck. Two weeks ago, he fell while playing in the sandbox and scraped his knees. He has not received any vaccinations since birth. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). He is diaphoretic. Examination shows inability to open his mouth beyond 1 cm. There is hyperextension of the lumbar spine and resistance to neck flexion. Administration of which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Capsular polysaccharide vaccines contain purified capsule antigens that are usually conjugated to a carrier protein (conjugate vaccine). Such vaccines are used to prevent infection with, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and N. meningitidis, all of which can cause meningitis. Although meningitis can present with fever and neck stiffness, trismus and opisthotonus are not characteristic features. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

B) INCORRECT:

Chemically-inactivated (whole-cell) viruses have been used as vaccines to prevent, e.g., polio (Salk vaccine), hepatitis A, and influenza virus infections. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

C) CORRECT:

Denatured C. tetani toxoid is used as a vaccination against tetanus. The still-intact receptor binding site of the toxoid induces antibody production and memory cell formation (active immunity). In patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, postexposure prophylaxis should include vaccination with DTaP and administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (HTIG). Management of tetanus includes antibiotic therapy and intensive care treatment.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of rabies. Administering preformed antibodies provides a passive immunity that, however, does not last long due to the antibodies' short half-life. Even though patients with rabies can present with trismus, opisthotonus, and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity, as seen in this patient, they also present with other characteristic features like hydrophobia and agitation. Furthermore, this patient has no history of an animal bite (e.g., by a bat or raccoon) that would raise suspicion for transmission of rabies. In post-exposure prophylaxis of tetanus, which is caused by a bacterium, not a virus, human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used against tetanus toxin.

E) INCORRECT:

Viable but weakened microorganisms are used in live attenuated vaccines for the prevention of, e.g., measles, mumps, rubella, varicella zoster, and rotavirus infection. These vaccines induce both cellular and humoral immune responses. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.
questions.hint: Generalized muscle spasms (trismus, mild opisthotonus, nuchal rigidity) and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity (fever, sweating) following a cutaneous injury in an unvaccinated child suggest tetanus, which is diagnosed clinically.
